Q: What was the “aha” moment that there was a need in the world for Mapbox
<!channel>: good to be here, thanks <@U07220RM3> <@U06QBQ0LF>!
<@U079PNFSR>: 2009 durring the Afghanistan election
Thanks <@U0B4K8Q4F> and <@U07TKB3K8>  for coming out. We really appreciate you doing this AMA. Mapbox we have a lot of Mapbox enthusiasts on this team and it’s great to have you here.
<@U07BUSV88|tmcgee> has joined the channel

<@U079K8TR8|cbley> has joined the channel

Q: What partnerships is Mapbox working on?
Thanks for doing this AMA! I’m curious where Mapbox fits into government and how have you showcased the tool stack in a world where ESRI tends to dominate?
In case you didn’t know, Eric is the CEO of Mapbox and Tom is one of the first engineers. So feel free to ask some technical questions and all things future, present and past Mapbox.

<@U0B4K8Q4F|gundersen> uploaded a file: <https://gisdevs.slack.com/files/gundersen/F0B4WSFU1/pasted_image_at_2015_09_22_11_04_am.png|the open data election browser we built for NDI and State, back in our Development Seed days.>

file.name: Pasted image at 2015_09_22 11_04 AM.png
file.title: the open data election browser we built for NDI and State, back in our Development Seed days.

text: the back story is kind of important to understanding why we started Mapbox
Q: What are the most influential projects making use of Mapbox?
before we were a “startup” and took outside funding we were heads down trying to help NGOs do more with data.
basically we built Mapbox for ourselves, we needed better mapping tools.
so we started building them ourself
in the open, on github
What would you recommend to get US Defense & Intelligence community to move its geospatial technology into this decade?
we funding the first 4 years of mapbox all off of consulting work
Q: Do you see Mapbox ever having a "professional services" division where they develop custom web and mobile apps tailored to specific organizational needs?
Mapbox has made a big impact on web mapping. Are there plans to add larger spatial analysis capabilities to impact that space?
How do you think the users used to tilemill/cartocss will adapt to the new version?
<@U0B4K8Q4F|gundersen> uploaded a file: <https://gisdevs.slack.com/files/gundersen/F0B4T5UCV/pasted_image_at_2015_09_22_11_07_am.png|This was the very first mapbox map with a mapbox logo on it>

file.name: Pasted image at 2015_09_22 11_07 AM.png
file.title: This was the very first mapbox map with a mapbox logo on it

text: <@U0A6NUXPZ>: we're still really getting started with the government angle: procurement has improved a ton recently, but it's still a very slow world to compete in. a lot of the government adoption we see of our tools is the open source side, which is super encouraging - that govt agencies can actually just build better tools for their really particular problems all on their own. both encouraging on an open source side, and also with government being more self-sufficient with tech
<@U0B4K8Q4F|gundersen> uploaded a file: <https://gisdevs.slack.com/files/gundersen/F0B4T33TR/pasted_image_at_2015_09_22_11_08_am.png|and one of our first terrain maps using SRTM in TileMill>

file.name: Pasted image at 2015_09_22 11_08 AM.png
file.title: and one of our first terrain maps using SRTM in TileMill

text: <@U0A6NUXPZ>: I would also add that Mapbox is highly complimentary with Esri, supporting even proprietary formats like FileGDB <https://www.mapbox.com/blog/tilemill-adds-support-for-esri-filegdb-format/>

attachments.title: TileMill adds support for Esri FileGDB format
attachments.text: TileMill now supports reading vector features directly from the proprietary Esri File Geodatabase (FileGDB) format. Interoperability with the FileGDB format is a major advance for Esri users that have adopted...
attachments.fallback: Mapbox: TileMill adds support for Esri FileGDB format

text: kkowalsky: i think people will be really happy with the post-cartocss world. i worked on cartocss for tilemill, and grew to understand all of its eccentricities. dropping it is going to be a big change, but it also really simplifies how maps are made in an important way: there's no magical transformation to mapnik xml behind the scenes, no pretending to be css. i thinkit's going to be a better platform for building on, and easier to learn once there are more resources in the wild
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: how are your enterprise sales going in general? Are you finding it difficult to reach larger enterprise clients who already have legacy systems in place
<@U07TKB3K8>: y’all will still support the old version or will it go the way of tilemill?
Excellent, thank you <@U07TKB3K8> and <@U0B4K8Q4F>!

<@U0A6NUXPZ>: In short I hope government can leverage our open source tools to extend their internal GIS - like <@U07TKB3K8> said, this stuff takes for even between procurement etc - what is nice about being open source is we get in faster.

kkowalsky: mapbox studio for desktop is now mapbox studio classic - we're planning on making sure it runs on newer versions of osx and fixing some long-well-known problems, but we won't be spending dev time building new features for it.
procurement :punch:
obviously, just like tilemill, it'll be open source forever so anyone and everyone is free to maintain or adapt it as they wish
cool! I’d hate to rewrite curriculum I JUST MADE for UW-Madison’s cartography program :blush:
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: Can you explain your love of Bud Light?

attachments.fallback: [September 22nd, 2015 11:13 AM] flippmoke: <@U0B4K8Q4F>: Can you explain your love of Bud Light?

text: <@U0B4T3BU5|tcql> pinned a message to this channel.
<@U07HRKFK6>: asking the important questions
Q: What (if any) lessons did you learn in wake of the awkward handling of vector tiles and mapbox-gl by Esri earlier this summer?
well, I didn’t *mean* to pin that, but it does seem important

robodonut: spatial analysis: first answer is that turfjs is where we tinker with spatial analysis - there are lots of parts of 'cartography' as the art form that are actually algorithmic, and we're constantly figuring out how to make those work better and faster
<@U0822V3BM|snorris> has joined the channel
Esri’s adoption of the Mapbox Vector Tile spec of the vector tile spec has also been great for open source integration with vector tiles <https://www.mapbox.com/blog/beautiful-mapbox-maps-with-esri/>

attachments.title: Your data managed in Esri, beautifully rendered with Mapbox on web and mobile
attachments.text: Esri’s adoption of the Mapbox Vector Tile spec opens the larger Mapbox open source toolbox to Esri users. A recent example is this Esri vector tile demo that was created...
attachments.fallback: Mapbox: Your data managed in Esri, beautifully rendered with Mapbox on web and mobile

text: <@U0B4K8Q4F>: I work for a startup. We're just starting to get some traction. What were your first 100 days like at Mapbox and when and why did you know that Mapbox was actually going to be a viable business?

> Q: What (if any) lessons did you learn in wake of the awkward handling of vector tiles and mapbox-gl by Esri earlier this summer?

And did it open up a line of communication to work better/closer with Esri?

robodonut: longer-term though, i like the quote 'any problem can be solved in O(n log n) time with the right data structure', and would say that spatial data in general has an odd mismatch of datastructure and intended usage. so we'd like to start with data structures and go out, rather than try to plug shapefiles into everything forever
<@U09P9M2FP|cmr.rose> has joined the channel
Huge thanks to <@U07C2GU81> for his help in the early days of getting in the door with Esri: <https://www.mapbox.com/blog/esri-tattoo/>

attachments.title: ArcGIS + MapBox Sitting in a Tree... Thanks to Arc2Earth
attachments.text: ArcGIS, and the larger Esri suite can be a used in powerful ways with MapBox. All that is needed is the Arc2Earth Sync plugin to bring your desktop GIS to...
attachments.fallback: Mapbox: ArcGIS + MapBox Sitting in a Tree... Thanks to Arc2Earth

text: Shapefiles are life, shapefiles are love
<@U07DGPFN3|jim2> has joined the channel
Is Mapbox Studio Minus CartoCSS available on github yet? When might it be?
Q: Where do you guys see turf.js in the next 5 years? Is there any functionality you want to add that you haven't yet?
<@U07C9MW9K|jbryant> has joined the channel
<@U06QBQ0LF> regarding enterprise adoption, and your question about viability, it happened when we started winning the make v buy decision for people looking for a new map API.

gisdev-km: sure, see <https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-js/pull/1377> - the team at esri is working on 'harmonizing' (ugh am i channeling ogc) their gl-js changes with our master fork. all hopes that it'll happen, though they've been pretty quiet so far.

text: <@U09P30DQ9|maximus28> has joined the channel
Our fist huge win was obviously Foursquare switching to Mapbox, like 3.5+ years ago
<@U092MH8R4|aaronpdennis> has joined the channel
It’s probably quiet as Chris is no longer with Esri...

<@U080X3Y2W> makes a good point, seems like mapbox is always pushing towards a moving target, and releasing great tools. But it is hard to pick where to invest time and energy to learn when the longevity of a tool or tech is unknown or unknowable. Do you think you will attach LTS status to any of the tools you release. Is the new Studio just that?
The technical team at Foursquare knew how important mapping was to their core platform, and liked our building block approach.

bddavidson: the biggest immediate priority for turf.js is breaking its dependency on jsts. longer-term i would love to focus on true numerical accuracy, customizable indexing for each algorithm, as well as cross-porting the whole thing between js & c++
This enterprise adoption has only grown. It has been amazing working with the MapQuest team: <http://techcrunch.com/2015/06/09/mapquest-confirms-mapbox-partnership/>

attachments.title: MapQuest Confirms It’s Using Mapbox To Overhaul Its Product
attachments.text: AOL-owned MapQuest has confirmed a big product and brand overhaul for its mapping product, including a partnership with developer mapping platform Mapbox to improve the product's performance. We reported these updates were incoming last month.
attachments.fallback: TechCrunch Link: MapQuest Confirms It’s Using Mapbox To Overhaul Its Product

text: Q: What qualities should have an engineer to work at Mapbox?
Q: How does the move toward vector tiles and GL affect the way you think about serving and processing the ever more massive and ubiquitous amounts of satellite raster data?
has everyone tried out the new maps? <http://beta.mapquest.com/>

attachments.title: Hello MapQuest
attachments.text: Wherever it is, we can help you get there.

text: nicholasm: i think i can safely say that  mapbox studio has been a larger and longer undertaking than tilemill or mapbox studio classic were, and it's the result of some real lessons learned.

it's frustrating from the outside to see tech churn, and honestly, also frustrating from the inside as well: we all wish everything was finished before it was finished, but you can only type so many chars at once
thanks <@U0B4K8Q4F>  looking forward to building some more integrations in the future
Mapbox 3D?
<@U09GNST4G> we look for engineers that have empathy, are great communicators, and wicked hungry.
Q: Is there any plans to release new Mapbox Studio as standalone application?
but mapbox studio has really landed somewhere that i think it'll last. we're going to keep working on it long after public release, and it's going to be amazing.
stepan: no, never. releasing desktop software has been unforgiving and torturous
Q) What has it been like hiring and working with remote engineers and employees. Yay or nay? Do you still hire remote workers?
<@U09GNST4G>: and most importantly we look for team members that want to grow. We don’t hire for based on who someone is or what they have done, we hire based on what we see someone growing into.
who’s idea were the banners outside the EsriUC? :simple_smile:

tylerdahlberg: the big change with vector tile processing is that it really formalizes this idea that mapmaking is (processing + design), and makes processing a first-class citizen. like, the most whiz-bang thing about mapbox studio is just that you can import a gigantic file and it gets magically turned into efficient vector tiles
<@U09GNST4G>: we have a repository on github “/recruiting” and when we come across someone who’s work we like or applies to <http://mapbox.com/jobs>, we start a ticket on them.
it has been critical for us to look outside traditional recruiting channels.
We are pushing hard on improving our diversity numbers

The new GL + the new Studio pretty clearly show your vision for map design and rendering.  But <@U07TKB3K8> I really appreciate your earlier point about focusing on the data—it all starts there.  Can you talk a bit about what you all are thinking about creating, managing, munging, etc. map data sources?
right now we are over 28% women, but that means we are just half way there.
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: did you know the Girls Who Code curriculum teaches mapbox.js??
But diversity means a lot of things. Best advise for other companies trying to improve diversity is to start talking about it.
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: is there any chance to get remote work at Mapbox if I am not a rock-star as <@U07TKB3K8> or mourner?
It’s amazing how just being super conscious helps you think smarter about recruiting.

I’m seeing an interesting evolution in geo-> the growth of the “geospatial web developer” this seems to be a skill set thats grown from technologies like MB & Carto etc but has history back to mapserver etc… the increased adoption of geo in general by the  developer community must be hugely exciting for your team?
we are trying to figure our remote honestly.

anand: the white whale of gis is a new shapefile, so yeah - our projects geobuf and cardboard are touch different sides of the storage & indexing equation. processing-wise i'm itching to get fancy new tech in production, but it's improving so quickly thanks to cross-pollination between mapnik, geojson-vt, and tippecanoe. those three projects, with wildly different personalities and approaches, have been so productively leaning towards really smart ways to tile out and process data.
How we use github, how we use slack, and how we communicate asynchronously is core to our foundation.
so we have been able to grow our team to ~30% remote. And that does not include being spread between DC -> SF -> Peru -> Bangalore

anand processing data is going to be some combination of 'processing engines that do _the right thing_ as well as manual control when that fails. right now we're moving so close in terms of algorithms making smart choices by default that i want to see how much further it can go before adding optimization knobs in a zany ui
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: Q) When did you guys figure out a pricing model that works and how did it change over time? How many people convert from the freemium to paid?
lol
Pricing is iterative
<@U08LZU9AM|aaron> has joined the channel
Q: how many of the engineering and other technical staff come from a traditional GIS/spatial background vs. something else? (I'm a software dev who happened to find himself in the spatial world)
it was so so so hard for us at first, because we were bootstrapped and the amount it costs us to run our infrastructure was real.
<@U093UF0F5|jlivni> has joined the channel
When we first launched Mapbox pricing the starter plan was $500 a month. That is because it costs us $250 a month to AWS, and that was regardless if you used the service or not.
<@U07TKB3K8>:  will geojson-vt support partial updates any time soon? and how do you see this affected the need to pre tile data sources?

willcadell: it definitely is. some people at mapbox have come from the gis/cartography/geology/environmental side of things, but lots of us are developers, and it's cool to see the problems of geo gain adherence. i really do think some of them are really neat intercepts of math-geo-art-data, and are just cool examples of combined concepts. routing has been that way forever - part of a core computer science curriculum - and i think other problems could join it
It took us like 18 months to roll out free plans. And I would say took us until the last 6 months to have good free plans that were not a joke.
<@U07TKB3K8>: how do you think, how soon will vector tiles be the new standard for web cartography?

bflood: pretiling & updating are separate problems in my mind - geojson-vt is usually used if the download time is _not_ a bottleneck, but interaction is. it will never be able to fix the download time problem, since it is on the client. that said, geojson-vt may get partial updates to support animation in mapbox-gl.

bflood: but webgl is a totally different ballgame than the dom and we're really starting from scratch for like 'how to partially update a buffer' at all, so maybe geojson-vt is the bottleneck there, and maybe it isn't - we shall wait for the benchmarks
<@U07TKB3K8>:  thanks! adding bbox

stepan: in the client? it will be years until there's like 95% adoption of webgl. but what matters on a technical level is that (1) they're the only real option for mobile and (2) on web, they've already been behind the scenes, powering our apis for well over a year
I appreciate the honest answers guys.  This is good stuff.
how many years, i don't know - i don't do predictions :simple_smile:
interestingly we haven’t seen vector tiles rolled out in the GMaps API either, its a big and difficult change
Thanks! :simple_smile:

Q: As Mapbox has grown more into web mapping building blocks and dev tools, what would you say are the tools / services you offer that a nonprofit could still take advantage of themselves with light geo / dev knowledge? What’s the best value Mapbox  provides to a nonprofit who can’t necessarily hire a GIS Analyst or Web developer?
for high-end visualizations, though, i think uptake will be much faster. there's a big difference between crazy interactive high-data maps and a normal ol' map portal
<@U07AMB5FZ|themapsmith> has joined the channel
<@U07TKB3K8>:  adding bbox query results or other tiled queries to a master geojson-vt on the client seems like a win, would allow for interacting with very larger data services (1M+) on the fly.
<@U0A79E7L4|miblon> has joined the channel
how many people <!here|@here> are doing maps on mobile and need a native SDK? _(raise your hands, I’m just wondering where the audience is focused)_
so, <@U0B4K8Q4F> who is going to buy who first: you guys or cartoDB? :wink:
<@U07220RM3>: we are not for sale
bflood: yep! if you know of any endpoints we should be testing out, let me know, i'm always interested in stress testing gl
On mobile, but with leaflet. No need for native
MPBX on the NYSE yeah?
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: I’ll give you $500. that’s my final offer
Until I can convince our IT dept to not buy phones on Sprint, mobile is dead here :disappointed:

<@U07220RM3>:  google maps api - they said it was something to do with lack of webgl support in browser (which doesn't make sense since <http://maps.google.com|maps.google.com> has been vector/webgl for some time)
This is not going to end with us commuting south on a bus.
No! Please leave cartodb alone. Or give it back tot Spain. Competition is bood!
Q: What other Mapbox curated global datasets are in the works? Besides Streets, Terrain, and Satellite, we’ve seen hints at weather on the blog.
Good
<@U07C2GU81> -> agreed i think building an API around vector tiles must be complex
Did you find fragmentation problems working with webgl? (Specially with the glsl part)
Q: If I was ever in the neighborhood during business hours, could I get a tour of the SF office? :simple_smile:
Q) <@U0B4K8Q4F>  Have you ever thought about acquiring Maptiks? I hear they have an awesome team and their tech is amazing.
do you see yourself as in competition with cartodb?
<@U06QBQ0LF> #shamelessplug
Love the team over at CartoDB. We have similar roots. Boot strapped, love good design, and love jamon serrano
<@U0A79E7L4>: haha
<@U0B4UN8Q6|smit1678> has joined the channel
<@U0B4Z2RQA|danpat> has joined the channel

bflood: distributing javascript libraries and encouraging people to install them on their websites is really a big promise to be making, so i'm not surprised google is being a little conservative, especially years ago when webgl was bleeding edge.
Q: is there any plans to release workflow to build tm2 source, like you did for TileMill OSM Bright (<https://github.com/mapbox/osm-bright>)?

attachments.text: osm-bright - A Carto template for OpenStreetMap data

text: Will webgl solve all of our problems?
<@U06QBQ0LF>: super impressed with maptiks. Analytics is hugely important. Not commenting on any strategic acquisitions, as a general rule.
javisantana: between chrome/firefox/safari not so much - bleeding-edge ie is still in the works, but major props to microsoft for being incredibly proactive in helping us get it running

<@U07TKB3K8>:  In relation to <@U0B4K8Q4F> 's native SDK question.  The work you guys have done on <https://github.com/mapbox/react-native-mapbox-gl> is amazing, but I wonder with your strong investment in native SDK teams if it's just experimental or something that will continue to mature.

text: we are also seeing an amazing renaissance in remote sensing -> planetlabs, astrodigital, DG, urthecast, skybox etc etc… how do you see that changing our space?
<@U09GNST4G>: is this what you were thinking? <https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-studio-osm-bright.tm2>

attachments.title: mapbox/mapbox-studio-osm-bright.tm2

text: <@U0AHG7946>: our iOS and Android SDKs are going to be our future.

geojson-vt :thumbsup:, Which reminds me. I benefit immensely from the open tools and tech you have developed and exposed, both personally (learning by coding and breaking things/putting them back together) and professionally (by using the tools and derivatives in work), so thanks for that. And I’m not alone, lot’s of folks here benefit without crawling too far up the paid plan ladder. Have there been any moments that challenged dedication to open source within Mapbox? Do you see/feel pressure growing to close some things off as adoption increases?

while webgl is often synonymous with 'playing with shaders', mapbox-gl is actually _very_ minimally into shader-trickery and we try to write extremely minimal, tested glsl code. as little as possible.
What about vector tiles data privacy. You talked about it briefly on twitter but I'd to read more about it
<@U07TKB3K8>: you're right but who knows why they haven't released one yet, they certainly have had the tech for quite some time. maybe <@U093UF0F5> can chime in :simple_smile:
<@U0AF91VQR|jharpster> has joined the channel
<@U07BKAV1N>: no, I'm thinking of source, not style itself, something like <https://github.com/stepankuzmin/osm-bright-2.tm2source>
<@U0B4YNXNW> in terms of the metic data we collect?
<@U09GNST4G>: i see
Like the location analytics for iOS? <https://www.mapbox.com/blog/mobile-location-analytics/>

attachments.title: Location analytics for iOS
attachments.text: Mobile location analytics are built into every developer’s account using the Mapbox Mobile iOS SDK, for free. The analytics dashboard is designed for developers to see how, when, and most...

text: sharkinsspatial: oh, we're absolutely going to keep working on the react-native-mapbox-gl project. react native has been doing nothing but winning recently, and we're already building fun little apps on it for testing. but right now, we'd rather put our resources at the core - at mapbox-gl-native, and then build around it

nicholasm: i work here because of open source. i wouldn't work at mapbox if we were another proprietary shop. there have totally been moments where some project or another isn't in a public repo, and, yeah - it's not as straightforward a decision as you would hope. but i'm really proud of what we did with <https://www.mapbox.com/about/open/> and been honest about what we open and why

<@U0B4K8Q4F>: How have your experiences been selling SaaS product to traditional organizations that have no idea how to deal with that from a procurement standpoint? (read: invoicing, annual billing, purchase orders, etc, even for small size outfits)
<@U0B4K8Q4F>: (question from above) we are also seeing an amazing renaissance in remote sensing -> planetlabs, astrodigital, DG, urthecast, skybox etc etc… how do you see that changing our space?
<@U09H72KNE|mizmay> has joined the channel
<@U07C6AJ0L>: good question
(just to do a quick driveby, Mapbox offers discounts for nonprofits and students/instructors through Mapbox Education: <https://mapbox.com/education> )
Q: <@U0B4K8Q4F> if mapbox makes enough profit, will you guys erect a real null island and can I come live there with my family? <https://twitter.com/nullislandbuoy>

text: <@U07TKB3K8>: good to hear.  On the React front stickshift and to-fix both look beautiful and are solid references, keep em coming.

<@U07C6AJ0L>: the biggest issue with pricing SaaS  has been us charging for mapviews. On one hand traffic is a good metric for success, and thus value based pricing. But the push back has always been with the free and $50 plans “what if my map goes viral”
and this happens.
miblon: moving to sao tome and principe would be close enough, right?

Not really a question. Just wanted to say I really appreciate Mapbox's commitment to empathetic training (via tutorials, examples, support staff). I'm not a developer at all, but much of what I've learned in the dev sphere is via y'all...so thanks.
What I hope you will see form us over the next 12 months is more focused on value based pricing, and less on raw API metering.
For example we have free geocoding, and we now have enterprise geocoding <https://twitter.com/Mapbox/status/643727263649804288>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/Mapbox|@Mapbox>: Hello Enterprise geocoding --> caching + batching + up to 30,000 requests per minute: <https://www.mapbox.com/geocoding> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CO76iIZUkAABsmX.png>
attachments.text: Hello Enterprise geocoding --> caching + batching + up to 30,000 requests per minute: <https://www.mapbox.com/geocoding> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CO76iIZUkAABsmX.png>

text: @tmwc; deal!
The big change here in pricing is charging for "equests per minute"
"Request up to 50 geocodes at a time"
charging on soft features that are super valuable for enterprise and don’t ding a lot of our free users

<@U0B4K8Q4F>: Maptiks is going to be integrating with Mapbox soon. Is there anyone at Mapbox that would be able or willing to help with a blog post or announcement. If you’re interested. Alright ladies and gents. It’s been 1 hour. I’d like to thank everyone for coming out. Eric and Tom thanks a lot for doing this AMA. It’s been very informative.
WOOT!!
You’re welcome to stick around for a bit and finish up answering questions, but you’re free to go.

:beers:
Thanks <@U0B4K8Q4F> and <@U07TKB3K8> <@U07TM5G65> <@U0B50DT0R> ….!

The big push in the micro satellite space is not going to be the imagery, but what you can do with it. I think in the next 12 months you are going to see vocabulary change from “big data” to "heavy data” - just not a lot of data that needs a lot of processing, but data that is hard to move around and expensive to store.

<@U091F24Q4>: imho, most important skill to learn is _how things work_. Being able to piece things together and make maps is one thing, but learning how systems work opens up a world of possibilities.
If you have any other questions or anything. Eric’s twitter is @ericg
agreed.. noone wants to process TBs of data…they want an answer or an email alert
And you can also follow Tom <@U07TKB3K8> on Twitter

Was just in a scrum with the Mapbox satellite team and heard that the the DigitalGlobe data processing is going to be 2.2 petabytes, re <http://techcrunch.com/2015/08/13/digitalglobe-partners-with-mapbox-to-launches-its-maps-api/>

attachments.title: DigitalGlobe Partners With Mapbox To Launch Its Maps API
attachments.text: DigitalGlobe, the publicly traded, high-res imagery service that owns its own fleet of satellites, has long been known as a purveyor of fine satellite imagery to governments and large companies like Google and Nokia. While these companies then often made DigitalGlobe's imagery available through their own developer programs, DigitalGlobe itself never focused on making its data available to smaller-sized startups and companies.
attachments.fallback: TechCrunch Link: DigitalGlobe Partners With Mapbox To Launch Its Maps API
